perturbation.original_text: 10.12. Dispute Resolution. (a) Any dispute, controversy or claim arising out of or relating to this Agreement, or the breach, termination or invalidity thereof (each, a “Dispute”), shall to the extent possible be settled through friendly consultation among the Parties hereto. The claiming Party (the “Claimant”) shall promptly notify the other Party (the “Respondent”) in a dated written notice that a Dispute has arisen and describe the nature of the Dispute. Any Dispute which remains unresolved within sixty (60) days after the date of such written notice shall be submitted to the China International Economic and Trade Arbitration Commission (the “Commission”) to be finally settled by arbitration in Beijing, PRC in accordance with the Commission’s then effective rules (the “Rules”) and this Section 10.12. The language of the arbitration shall be Mandarin Chinese.
perturbation.changed_text: 10.12. Dispute Resolution. (a) Any dispute, controversy or claim arising out of or relating to this Agreement, or the breach, termination or invalidity thereof (each, a “Dispute”), shall to the extent possible be settled through friendly consultation among the Parties hereto. The claiming Party (the “Claimant”) shall promptly notify the other Party (the “Respondent”) in a dated written notice that a Dispute has arisen and describe the nature of the Dispute. Any Dispute which remains unresolved within sixty (60) days after the date of such written notice shall be submitted to a mediator in a location of mutual agreement, but this agreement to mediate will not be binding, or require any party to settle in that location.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause mandates arbitration in Beijing. The modified clause moves the dispute resolution to mediation, but states that the mediation agreement is not binding. This creates a legal contradiction. The contract initially specifies a clear and binding arbitration process, but the modification allows either party to disregard the mediation agreement, making the dispute resolution process uncertain and unenforceable. The original text follows PRC law for arbitration, while the altered text renders the dispute resolution mechanism non-binding.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Arbitration Law of the People's Republic of China

perturbation.original_text: 10.1. Taxes. Each Party shall be responsible for taxes that should be borne by it in accordance with applicable Law. If any Party pays any taxes that should have been borne by the other Party in accordance with Law, such other Party shall reimburse such Party within seven (7) days after its receipt of documentation evidencing such tax payment so incurred by such Party.
perturbation.changed_text: 10.1. Taxes. Each Party shall be responsible for taxes that should be borne by it in accordance with applicable Law. If any Party pays any taxes that should have been borne by the other Party in accordance with Law, such other Party may reimburse such Party within seven (7) days after its receipt of documentation evidencing such tax payment so incurred by such Party.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause states the second party 'shall' reimburse the first. This new clause changes 'shall' to 'may'. The reimbursement of taxes is now optional, creating a contradiction of whether taxes are to be reimbursed.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Tax Laws of the People's Republic of China

perturbation.original_text:
6.3. Termination for Breach.
(a) By Licensor. Licensor may terminate this Agreement at any time in the event that the Licensee is in material default or breach of any provision of this Agreement, and, if such default or breach is capable of cure, such default or breach continues uncured for a period of thirty (30) days after receipt of written notice thereof; provided, however, that in the event that the Licensee has in good faith commenced cure within such thirty (30) day period, but cannot practically complete such cure within such thirty (30) day period, the Parties shall negotiate a reasonable additional time to cure.
perturbation.changed_text:
6.3. Termination for Breach.
(a) By Licensor. Licensor may terminate this Agreement at any time in the event that the Licensee is in material default or breach of any provision of this Agreement, and, if such default or breach is capable of cure, such default or breach continues uncured for a period of thirty (30) days after receipt of written notice thereof; provided, however, that in the event that the Licensee has in good faith commenced cure within such thirty (30) day period, but cannot practically complete such cure within such thirty (30) day period, the Parties shall instead agree to a full waiver of the breach.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause states that the parties would negotiate a cure period. This change makes the parties agree to a full waiver, which is in contradiction to the original provision, introducing legal uncertainty.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law of the People's Republic of China
